employers.name: IBM
employers.featuredReview.headline: If you can struggle through and hold on to the right hands, you can make it big.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Exposure and diverse experience...too many options to explore within the company
employers.featuredReview.cons: Too large to be lost, old tedious admin activities
employers.ceo.name: Virginia Rometty
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: J.P. Morgan
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great company/Bank
employers.featuredReview.pros: Brand name and great bank
employers.featuredReview.cons: career progression and work life balance
employers.ceo.name: Jamie Dimon
employers.ceo.title: Chairman, President, and CEO

employers.name: Citi
employers.featuredReview.headline: Positive experience
employers.featuredReview.pros: Great team & plentiful opportunities to learn and grow
employers.featuredReview.cons: Large organization that can be divided into silos
employers.ceo.name: Michael Corbat
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: Macy's
employers.featuredReview.headline: Retail sales associate
employers.featuredReview.pros: Great deal, meeting people and growing learning how to sell
employers.featuredReview.cons: Competitive people, having to stand on foot
employers.ceo.name: Terry J. Lundgren
employers.ceo.title: Chairman & CEO

employers.name: Morgan Stanley
employers.featuredReview.headline: Good company, great people messy management, politics galore.
employers.featuredReview.pros: The people and technology at Morgan are superb. There is almost a culture of intelligence that has been created there. After leaving MS, i realized how valuable it is to work in environment with tons of people.
employers.featuredReview.cons: I had 4 direct managers in 3 years and 3 department heads in 3 years. Constant churn, constant change of direction.
employers.ceo.name: James P. Gorman
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: PwC
employers.featuredReview.pros: Really enjoy working here. Work hard for a few months, take it easy for the rest. When you work hard they still treat you right. PwC does things well and treats their employees with respect.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Nothing comes to my mind at all.
employers.ceo.name: Robert Moritz
employers.ceo.title: US Chairman & Senior Partner

employers.name: Goldman Sachs
employers.featuredReview.headline: best experience
employers.featuredReview.pros: it was pretty fun in terms of work and social life. good money and awesome city to be at. I totaly recommend this
employers.featuredReview.cons: not really cons. I would say for some of my peers, they had hard work in terms of the hours. I would say the con ids that you don;t get payment for over time.
employers.ceo.name: Lloyd C. Blankfein
employers.ceo.title: Chairman and CEO

employers.name: Bloomberg L.P.
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great company to work for if you are smart, engaged and outgoing
employers.featuredReview.pros: I worked at Bloomberg for over 8 years. I was able to move to different departments. If you do a good job and they like you as a person, you will definitely be well compensated. Compensation and bonus depends on how much profit your department makes though. If you are smart and a go getter, it is easy to move up the ladder to become a team leader or manager. People who work there are really nice and helpful.
employers.featuredReview.cons: People who have been there a long time and complacent are being "let go" and replaced by younger people for half the price.
employers.ceo.name: Dan Doctoroff
employers.ceo.title: President and CEO

employers.name: Deloitte
employers.featuredReview.headline: Generally a terrific company to work for with lots of opportunity for challenging client service work.
employers.featuredReview.pros:
Stable consulting platform from an operational standpoint
Prestigious firm with a strong brand
Broad client service offerings
employers.featuredReview.cons:
Heavy on the overhead costs and management
HR department runs too much of how things get done
Promotion of people that are not as well qualified as others simply due to management being rewarded to promote certain classes of personnel so that Best Places to Work For rankings can stay high
employers.ceo.name: Barry Salzberg
employers.ceo.title: Global CEO

employers.name: EY
employers.featuredReview.headline: EY is a great company to work for. They offer amazing benefits.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Benefits, flexible work hours, challenging work, and building lifelong relationships.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Work can be stressful and long hours during busy season.
employers.ceo.name: Mark Weinberger
employers.ceo.title: Global Chairman and CEO

employers.name: American Express
employers.featuredReview.headline: It's all about trust and your personal brand.
employers.featuredReview.pros: The company is truly focused on the setting expectations appropriately with all stakeholders, including shareholders, customers and employees.  Success is typically found among those who can propose a vision and then deliver according to plan, neither promising too much nor too little. This leads to reliability and eventually trust - the most regarded currency at the company.
employers.featuredReview.cons: The company has challenges linking strategy to tactics. A lot of this seems to develop from a very top heavy organization structure. Goals are set and tasks are assigned, but much depends on middle management to connect the two. More can be done to improve and when it's not, it becomes a real problem, not only for mid level VPs, but their teams as well. The number one concern of an employee is whether his/her leader offers a clear vision for the team.
employers.ceo.name: Ken Chenault
employers.ceo.title: Chairman and CEO

employers.name: Bank of America
employers.featuredReview.headline: There is a lot of work and you have to learn to work in a high pressured environment.
employers.featuredReview.pros: The work is fine and the people are great to work with on a daily basis.
employers.featuredReview.cons: The pay can be better for the work we do.
employers.ceo.name: Brian T. Moynihan
employers.ceo.title: President & CEO

employers.name: Columbia University
employers.featuredReview.headline: Worked as a RA in department of Biomedical Informatics at CUMC
employers.featuredReview.pros: Pay more than morning side campus
employers.featuredReview.cons: work is intensive, which is totally depend on your advisor
employers.ceo.name: Lee C. Bollinger
employers.ceo.title: President and Trustee

employers.name: Credit Suisse
employers.featuredReview.headline: i really enjoyed how I was able to learn and grow while working at Credit Suisse.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Working at this company is a good opportunity to learn and grow as a individual to enhance ones skills.
employers.featuredReview.cons: It is a fast paced environment and you have to be able to meet deadlines. You have to be flexible to wear different hats to get the job done.
employers.ceo.name: Brady W. Dougan
employers.ceo.title: CEO, Credit Suisse Group and Credit Suisse

employers.name: Thomson Reuters
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great experience, but highly dependent on department placed
employers.featuredReview.pros: Exciting media and tech company
employers.featuredReview.cons: Company has been going through challenges
employers.ceo.name: James C. Smith
employers.ceo.title: President & CEO

employers.name: BNY Mellon
employers.featuredReview.headline: Internship
employers.featuredReview.pros: People are very nice and caring
employers.featuredReview.cons: Jobs seems to be a bit repetitive, again it is based on only 1 month of experience. I think you can learn a lot there
employers.ceo.name: Gerald Hassell
employers.ceo.title: Chairman, President and CEO

employers.name: NYU (New York University)
employers.featuredReview.headline: IT Support Analyst
employers.featuredReview.pros: Fair and knowledgable bosses. When there's a time conflict with classes, they understand the student's priorities, and are willing to accommodate.
employers.featuredReview.cons: No bad experiences or scenarios come to mind
employers.ceo.name: John E. Sexton
employers.ceo.title: President

employers.name: KPMG US
employers.featuredReview.headline: Senior associate, advisory
employers.featuredReview.pros: Great place to learn and opportunities to grow
employers.featuredReview.cons: Could be too fast paced so you need to keep up
employers.ceo.name: John B. Veihmeyer
employers.ceo.title: Chairman & CEO

employers.name: Xerox
employers.featuredReview.headline: vgood
employers.featuredReview.pros: salary and work both are good
employers.featuredReview.cons: i cant say any cons
employers.ceo.name: Ursula M. Burns
employers.ceo.title: Chairman and CEO

employers.name: New York City Department of Education
employers.featuredReview.headline: Teacher
employers.featuredReview.pros: Fulfilling profession and administration is understanding.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Many constraints and guidelines to follow.
employers.ceo.name: Carmen Farina
employers.ceo.title: Chancellor

employers.name: Deutsche Bank
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great so far
employers.featuredReview.pros:
Great work life balance
Lots of vacation days
employers.featuredReview.cons: Nothing that comes to mind
employers.ceo.name: Jürgen Fitschen & Anshu Jain
employers.ceo.title: Co-Chairmen & CEO

employers.name: Target
employers.featuredReview.headline: Nice place to work.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Great starter job. Fast paced job.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Management  was constantly changing. They barely knew you to give reviews.
employers.ceo.name: Brian Cornell
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: Chase
employers.featuredReview.headline: personal banker
employers.featuredReview.pros: It is what you make of it.. At the time I was employed with Chase, investment and life insurance licensing was being offered- This allowed for good commission..
employers.featuredReview.cons: I do not have any real cons. More of an opinion: At the end of the day, this is retail banking. If looking to break into other areas of finance (corporate banking, IB, etc.) this may not be the best route
employers.ceo.name: Jamie Dimon
employers.ceo.title: Chairman and CEO, JPMorgan Chase

employers.name: Barclays Capital
employers.featuredReview.headline: Back office consultant
employers.featuredReview.pros: Flexible and decent paying back office consultant positions, I found the employees there to be very friendly and helpful to inexperienced hires.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Hours can be long but this should be expected in finance, technology was antiquated,  and red tape abounds.
employers.ceo.name: Antony Jenkins
employers.ceo.title: Group CEO

employers.name: Cornell University
employers.featuredReview.headline: grad student
employers.featuredReview.pros: very good! our Cs facilities were great and it was a great place to learn to do good research. good funding for work and fun.
employers.featuredReview.cons: of course being in Ithaca can be challenging due to the harsh winters. but you figurei to ut, you deal.
employers.ceo.name: David J. Skorton
employers.ceo.title: President

employers.name: Accenture
employers.featuredReview.headline: Learn fast. Work hard. But, likely move on.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Highly process-focused, matrixed and hierarchical organization built on respected principals and deep capabilities across virtually every area of service and country on the globe.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Continuous focus on and expectation around individual and team high performance translates to long, intense hours (often short-handed) and focus on quarterly earnings to meet sales and margin targets. Personal and operational goals don't always translate to advancement and there is an unwritten understanding of '5 years up or out' to partner if you are an experienced hire.  The 'laddering' process (ranking of peers within a practice) can be subjective and there are limits to upward mobility beyond the senior manager level.
employers.ceo.name: Pierre Nanterme
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: AIG
employers.featuredReview.headline: Used to be a Solid Employer
employers.featuredReview.pros: Good Work/Life Balance: Good Time Off
employers.featuredReview.cons: Lots of quiet large lay offs; constantly changing executive management plans; executives constantly providing promotional opportunities for themselves; lack of promotional opportunities or opportunities to move around the company laterally; lots of dead end departmental positions; executive management has no interest in knowing the real talent within all levels of the company and making sure they are in the right position rather than just performing lay offs; good salaries going in but lack of performance based increases (lots of "you performed exceptionally well this year but no one, but the executives, are getting raises this year".
employers.ceo.name: Peter Hancock
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: Best Buy
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great
employers.featuredReview.pros: Discounts  customer service employee perks  pay rate
employers.featuredReview.cons: Hours, work life balance black friday
employers.ceo.name: Hubert Joly
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: Starbucks
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great benefits, management does not practice what it preaches.
employers.featuredReview.pros:
Staff is great
really good benefits 
Flexible hours
Great Training
Personal days plus a good system for vacation time the longer you've been there
employers.featuredReview.cons:
Customers can be a pain
Managers incentivized to not stock the store/staff properly
The hours are flexible, but you can go insane waking up at 4am one day, and working til midnight the next day
employers.ceo.name: Howard D. Schultz
employers.ceo.title: Chairman, President, and CEO

employers.name: MTV Networks
employers.featuredReview.headline: Working at MTV networks was very beneficial. It taught me how to maneuver within Corporate America.
employers.featuredReview.pros: It affords you the opportunity to meet a lot of movers and shakers and valuable connections. I was able to build a network of professionals that helped make my job in marketing easier.
employers.featuredReview.cons: The pay isn't competitive. Because so many people are eying to work at MTV Networks they are able to pay pennies and hire quality professionals.
employers.ceo.name: Philippe P. Dauman
employers.ceo.title: President and CEO, Viacom

employers.name: Time Warner Cable
employers.featuredReview.headline: Good Pay if you Work for it.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Great Payout. It is a Desk Job.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Days seem long, Always disputing orders because of stolen sales, commission based Getting yelled at by customers all day.
employers.ceo.name: Robert D. Marcus
employers.ceo.title: Chairman & CEO

employers.name: Apple
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great retail job!
employers.featuredReview.pros: Cool people, cool tech, cool work environment.
employers.featuredReview.cons: If you wanna grow, you need to spend the time being there
employers.ceo.name: Tim Cook
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: Pfizer
employers.featuredReview.headline: Day to Day challenges. Never a dull day.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Challenging Work. Lots of Big Company perks. Ok Salary. Great People to talk to.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Leadership is blind to ongoing strife. No real chances for promotion. Micromanagement from Middle Management while Upper Management is more trusting of its work force.
employers.ceo.name: Ian Read
employers.ceo.title: President & CEO

employers.name: The Home Depot
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great company to work for although the pay rate is mediocre at best.
employers.featuredReview.pros:
Company Cares for employee needs and tends to be on the side of employees as long as they are correct.
Has a strong core value and tries to live up to it.
Managers not only listen but act to help needs of employees
employers.featuredReview.cons:
Very low wages. Full time pay started at less than 25 thousand a year. 
High intensity work conditions.
employers.ceo.name: Craig Menear
employers.ceo.title: President & CEO

employers.name: NBCUniversal
employers.featuredReview.headline: Fun and efficient
employers.featuredReview.pros: It was a lot of fun to be an NBC intern. The internship program is very structured and they spend a lot of time making sure you get the most out of your summer experience with them. You get the opportunity to hear many important people speak about a wide range of topics and you get a chance to be a part of a venerable institution. They really value their interns, unlike many companies. Also a great place to have a connection with for after graduation - there are always new openings throughout the company.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Their policy is that interns can only work 2.5 days a week, so if you're hoping for a full-time position for the summer, this won't be it.
employers.ceo.name: Stephen B. Burke
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: GLOBALFOUNDRIES
employers.featuredReview.headline: There are a lot of benefits for working for a newer company but also a lot of negative aspects.
employers.featuredReview.pros:
There is opportunity for growth.
There are new opportunities.
employers.featuredReview.cons:
There are lots of managerial changes, causing unhappy work atmosphere.
There are a lot of "viruses", people who are clearly not happy working there which leads to multiple people giving off the same outlook. 
There is not enough time in the day to fix the issues many people are giving out which sometimes causes frustration and anger.
employers.ceo.name: Sanjay K. Jha
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: Verizon
employers.featuredReview.jobTitle: Lead Systems Consultant - Systems Analysis & Programs
employers.featuredReview.jobTitleFromDb: Lead Systems Consultant - Systems Analysis & Programs
employers.featuredReview.headline: Verizon
employers.featuredReview.pros: Awesome company. Excellent brand, as a programmer analyst it has allowed me to experience a large scale enterprise programming enviornment. Lots of room for growth
employers.featuredReview.cons: Compensation not as high Compared to the industry
employers.ceo.name: Lowell McAdam
employers.ceo.title: President & CEO

employers.name: McDonald's
employers.featuredReview.headline: Very Friendly, fast pace environment
employers.featuredReview.pros: The best part is being able to be yourself & be happy at work.
employers.featuredReview.cons: customers sometimes like to make you feel like you aren't anything only because you work at a fast food restaurant.
employers.ceo.name: Don Thompson
employers.ceo.title: President & CEO

employers.name: Citibank
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great benefits and compensation.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Their health benefits are top notch,the plans that they offer give you many different options, hard to beat their choices.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Turnover due to managements rigid way of doing things within branches is horrible, the turnover makes the customers unhappy, which makes our job harder.
employers.ceo.name: Michael Corbat
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: Memorial Sloan Kettering
employers.featuredReview.headline: Fantastic organization to start a career in healthcare.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Great benefits; driven coworkers that bring the best out of you; and many opportunities to grow.
employers.featuredReview.cons: As a very large organization, it is a bit intimidating at first. I came in as an RSA and eventually found my stride in the clinical practice plan.
employers.ceo.name: Craig B. Thompson
employers.ceo.title: President & CEO

employers.name: Walmart
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great foundation. There are many process in place that in the perfect walmart world would work great.
employers.featuredReview.pros: High base pay. Benefits on day 1 of employment.
employers.featuredReview.cons: You will be spoken to and yell at as if you were a child.
employers.ceo.name: Doug McMillon
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: CVS Health
employers.featuredReview.headline: Times they are a changin'
employers.featuredReview.pros: The in-store dynamic can be intricate and be a great place to work. Promotions are obtainable relatively easily. The work can be rewarding.
employers.featuredReview.cons: The company doesn't adequately value the effort of its store employees. Time-off is an issue for many periods throughout the year. Heavy workload with skeleton budgets. Serious disconnect between company initiatives and store needs.
employers.ceo.name: Larry J. Merlo
employers.ceo.title: President and CEO

employers.name: Merrill Lynch
employers.featuredReview.headline: Fantastic investment banking experience
employers.featuredReview.pros: Entrepreneurial environment, staffed on interesting and high-profile transactions, Great Pay
employers.featuredReview.cons: Long hours and poor work/life balance
employers.ceo.name: Brian T. Moynihan
employers.ceo.title: President & CEO of Bank of America

employers.name: HSBC Bank USA
employers.featuredReview.headline: Premier Relationship Mgr
employers.featuredReview.pros: Base plus incentive and with good benefits. Good colleagues and clean work environment. International branding and well known in the market. They are very good at attracting a wealth customer and offering products to fit their needs.
employers.featuredReview.cons: A lot of prospecting and aggressive goals
employers.ceo.name: Irene Dorner
employers.ceo.title: Chief Executive Officer

employers.name: UBS
employers.featuredReview.headline: It was a good place to work at but lacked communication internally
employers.featuredReview.pros: great place to start a career. People were very interested in mentoring and was able to have a lot of responsibilities early on.
employers.featuredReview.cons:
Internally there was a lack of communication from mgmt to the rest of the team. 

Felt that producers were not fairly compensated at the appropriate times.
employers.ceo.name: Sergio P. Ermotti

employers.name: Condé Nast
employers.featuredReview.headline: Very happy
employers.featuredReview.pros: Good editors, fun environment, prestige publications, great exposure

employers.ceo.name: Chuck Townsend
employers.ceo.title: President and CEO

employers.name: Time
employers.featuredReview.headline: A great company in transition
employers.featuredReview.pros: Great co-workers, opportunities for advancement, constant learning opportunities, work/life balance, benefits
employers.featuredReview.cons: Job security, low morale, struggling through an enormous culture change
employers.ceo.name: Joseph A. Ripp

employers.featuredReview.headline: Not what they claim to be
employers.featuredReview.pros: they have earning potential and location

employers.name: PepsiCo

employers.featuredReview.pros: The lab that I worked in had a good vibe, everyone was very motivated and worked to make sure that I succeeded in the program.
employers.featuredReview.cons: With such a large company, it's hard to see opportunities for personal growth. However, if you work hard and do well ideally you will be rewarded.
employers.ceo.name: Indra K. Nooyi

employers.name: Abercrombie & Fitch

employers.featuredReview.cons: You must greet every customer who walks in. even messing up a little gets you in big trouble.
employers.ceo.name: Mike Jeffries
employers.ceo.title: Chairman and CEO

employers.name: Eastman Kodak
employers.featuredReview.headline: Formerly one of the best, now struggling to be it again.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Good people, high ethics, professionalism, good engineering skills, people help each other more than compete with each other.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Struggling in today's markets, a shell of what it once was.  The top engineering talent has left to other opportunities, the people left are often the "C"team.  Not being negative, just honest.
employers.ceo.name: Jeffrey J. Clarke
employers.ceo.title: Chief Executive Officer

employers.ceo.name: James L. Dolan
employers.ceo.title: President, CEO, and Director;  Chairman, Madison Square Garden; and Governor, New York Knicks

employers.featuredReview.headline: An amazing growth experience
employers.featuredReview.pros: Smart people, ethical management, care about doing the right thing.

employers.ceo.name: Richard W. Edelman

employers.name: Bloomingdale's

employers.featuredReview.pros:
Amazing manager
Plenty chances to grow within the company
Great staff

employers.ceo.name: Tony Spring
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: Google
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great place to work!

employers.featuredReview.headline: Associate - Client Service
employers.featuredReview.pros: Worked with bright, motivated people
employers.featuredReview.cons: Competitive and intense, lots of overhead
employers.ceo.name: Laurence D. Fink
employers.ceo.title: Chairman and CEO

employers.name: Wegmans Food Markets
employers.featuredReview.headline: Very accommodating managers, great group of people.
employers.featuredReview.pros: The people are great, from managers to HR to fellow employees. You can tell Wegmans puts a lot of work into hiring good customer-focused people. The managers make you feel at home from day one. Free food sometimes and other occasional perks.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Managers move to other stores regularly. Tough to work nights. You might expect to get paid a bit more at Wegmans, but pay is average for the job.
employers.ceo.name: Danny Wegman
employers.ceo.title: Chairman and CEO

employers.name: Paychex
employers.featuredReview.headline: Your happiness may depend upon the group you work for
employers.featuredReview.pros: If you're in the right group it can be very rewarding, with competitive pay and wonderful co-workers.
employers.featuredReview.cons: There are groups that have an incredible amount of pressure on them, and they seem stuck in a culture of deflecting and delaying over serving the teams they interact with.
employers.ceo.name: Martin Mucci
employers.ceo.title: President and CEO

employers.name: The Gap
employers.featuredReview.headline: The best brand to work for.
employers.featuredReview.pros: The friendliest work environment possible. Great leadership, perfect work-life balance, and lots of growth opportunities.
employers.featuredReview.cons: I truthfully cannot find any cons about working for this company.
employers.ceo.name: Art Peck
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: GE
employers.featuredReview.headline: Good company to work for
employers.featuredReview.pros: coworkers worked well together good benefits
employers.featuredReview.cons: downsizing. company and depts. constantly changing gears
employers.ceo.name: Jeffrey R. Immelt
employers.ceo.title: Chairman & CEO

employers.name: Polo Ralph Lauren
employers.featuredReview.headline: Nice atmosphere
employers.featuredReview.pros: The discount is very good, and it gets better around holiday season. You get a good amount of hours. They accomodate your scheduling needs with no problems. Small raise after about 3-4 months. If you set your availablitily for weekends, you will definately be working weekends.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Sometimes push you to bother customers ultiple time which I was uncomfrtable with.
employers.ceo.name: Ralph Lauren
employers.ceo.title: Chairman and CEO

employers.name: Lowe's
employers.featuredReview.headline: asm
employers.featuredReview.pros: Great company to work for many opportunities to grow..benefits are also great.
employers.featuredReview.cons: These are big box retailers so you are dealing with maybe 1500 customers per day double that on holidays. This will keep you busy throughout your shift. Customer can sometimes be very rude.
employers.ceo.name: Robert A. Niblock
employers.ceo.title: Chairman and CEO

employers.name: Avon Products
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great company for women struggling to survive
employers.featuredReview.pros: The company's commitment to breast cancer, domestic violence and empowering women is the reason to work here.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Avon's business is on the decline and despite a new CEO and a turnaround plan, the company is struggling -- especially in North America. Layoffs occur at least one a year.
employers.ceo.name: Sheri S. McCoy
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: US Army
employers.featuredReview.headline: I served four years in the United States Army as an Intelligence Analyst. It was an honor to serve.
employers.featuredReview.pros: It was a challenging job that requires soldiers to take initiative, and always demanding. Soldiers develop a great sense of community and comradery with fellow soldiers which makes it unforgettable.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Demanding work with a very strong bureaucratic structure. It is easy to get caught up in the "hurry up and wait" mentality, because much of it stateside is maintenance-based.
employers.ceo.name: John McHugh
employers.ceo.title: Secretary

employers.name: S&P Ratings
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great company.  Unfortunately, they have been going through reductions in staff.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Many products to sell and a great brand name.  I sold company data and international securities identifiers.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Too much turnover lately.  Company values have gone done on personal levels.
employers.ceo.name: Neeraj Sahai
employers.ceo.title: President

employers.name: Viacom
employers.featuredReview.headline: Very impressed
employers.featuredReview.pros:
The environment is warm and all of the employees I've met were welcoming and kind. In this fast paced industry, Viacom gets the job done. 
The internship program is one of the best I've seen.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Because it's such a big company, it might be difficult to connect with supervisors, and you may just be a number.

employers.name: AT&T
employers.featuredReview.headline: A great place to be in wireless
employers.featuredReview.pros: AT&T helped me grow as a person with good pay, paid time off and 401.  There is a constant amount of training to keep you fully up on the latest in consumer tech.  Company provided devices are great to learn on.  The company is transitioning to a leadership position in the internet of things and you'll see quite a few cool things working there.
employers.featuredReview.cons: The hours are long, especially for the frontlines.  Turnover can create interesting challenges in small stores.  So many things to sell with new product launches can get overwhelming.  It's difficult to get promoted without making Summit.

employers.featuredReview.headline: Verizon has an exceptional training program that helps people of all skills control how successful they are.
employers.featuredReview.pros: It is an awesome place to meet new people and learn to better interact with people of all demographics. There is longevity when selling something that EVERYONE NEEDs. Verizon Wireless is the number one rated wireless network in the USA.
employers.featuredReview.cons: It is very difficult to get promoted to an RD position in Verizon Wireless. The hours are long, especially on holidays.  When dealing with sales, paid vacation is rare and not worth taking too much time away from the money.

employers.name: United Nations
employers.featuredReview.headline: Internship Experience
employers.featuredReview.pros: Highly competent co-workers, extremely friendly and diverse staff. Everyone was very willing to expose you to different areas of the office and the projects they are working on.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Work load and pace was slower than I would have liked, but summer is a slower time of year for the office.
employers.ceo.name: Ban Ki-moon
employers.ceo.title: Secretary-General

employers.name: HBO
employers.featuredReview.headline: Couldn't have asked for a better internship.
employers.featuredReview.pros: HBO's internship program is very structured and involves lots of great networking/learning opportunities, including speaker series with execs and a summer-long project that all the interns work on together. There were 50 interns in NYC, all spread out throughout many departments. My manager was incredibly clear, approachable, and helpful, and gave me plenty of meaningful work to do. From what I've heard, most other interns had similar experiences. HBO also pays interns quite well by entertainment industry standards - $15/hr.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Virtually none. I wasn't a huge fan of "Project HBO," the intern project we all worked on (didn't always seem like a meaningful use of time), but everything else was great.
employers.ceo.name: Richard Plepler
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: Moody's
employers.featuredReview.headline: Summer at Moody's
employers.featuredReview.pros: Working at Moody's was a great experience where I saw a variety of legal issues in a collegial, laid-back working environment. I particularly enjoyed it because I got along very well with my supervisor, which can't be guaranteed for everyone.
employers.featuredReview.cons: It seems like some of the analysts are looking to make moves to BBs and don't seem to want to stay at Moody's to develop their career there. A bit of office politics, and sometimes not fast-paced enough.
employers.ceo.name: Ray McDaniel Jr.
employers.ceo.title: Chairman and CEO

employers.name: NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital
employers.featuredReview.headline: Rewarding place to volunteer
employers.featuredReview.pros: The hospital provides extensive training and orientation for volunteers so that they are very well prepared to handle almost anything.
employers.featuredReview.cons: I would not change a thing! The training and orientation are truly outstanding.
employers.ceo.name: Steven J. Corwin
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: GEICO
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great company
employers.featuredReview.pros: As long as your willing to work hard the opportunities for growth are there.
employers.featuredReview.cons: Only days of are standard Christmas, thanksgiving etc won't get other days such as MLK and other federal holidays but they do give you four floating holidays throughout the year to compensate.
employers.ceo.name: Olza (Tony) Nicely
employers.ceo.title: Chairman and CEO

employers.name: Barnes & Noble
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great place to work
employers.featuredReview.pros:
High Customer focus - Customers are always a priority and always come first.
Relaxed atmosphere - managers expect booksellers to complete daily tasks but never at the expense of the customer.
Intellectual customers - As a bookseller, I enjoy interacting with the B&N customer because most are above average and conversations are always interesting and stimulating.
Flexible hours - many different shifts are available to accommodate individual needs.  Also varying shifts make each day different and provide more variety to my week.  Management also supports and encourages a good work/life balance.
On-the-job training gets a newcomer involved immediately.  Co-worker support is stressed and part of the corporate culture.
Amazing benefits at the full time level (health care, vision, dental 401K).
Great discounts (books, cafe, bookseller appreciation around the holidays).
Upward mobility - fast promotions - a lot of opportunities for advancement.
employers.featuredReview.cons:
Salary is not competitive.
Management is not consistent.  A bookseller can ask the same question to three different managers and get three different responses which is very confusing.
On-the-job training can be frustrating because of inconsistent management.  Also it is difficult to get the "big picture" because so much training is done at a very detailed level.  In addition, due to the upward mobility, managers are frequently transferred to different locations which adds to the management instability.
employers.ceo.name: Michael Huseby
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: MetLife
employers.featuredReview.headline: Great company with lots of opportunities.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Brand recognition, lots of ways to learn, grow. Decent support from management team(depends on which MD you are with)
employers.featuredReview.cons: Technology, IT sucks. Sales pressure(but, reasonable), conservative company culture.
employers.ceo.name: Steven A. Kandarian
employers.ceo.title: President & CEO

employers.name: Forever 21
employers.featuredReview.headline: Forever 21
employers.featuredReview.pros: No hours in the store because this is a new location. They same to have favorites there also .......
employers.featuredReview.cons: Great people.and the girls are nice looking. IF your a young man and can't get a girl working at forever 21 you just dint want one
employers.ceo.name: Do Won "Don" Chang
employers.ceo.title: Co-Founder and CEO

employers.name: Victoria's Secret Stores
employers.featuredReview.headline: Greatttt company - seems promising for more opportunities
employers.featuredReview.pros: The company and company atmosphere is awesome. Everyone has and knows their job so there's no confusion. I like the organization and the fact that the stress level of the employees are low and so are attitudes. Everyone is quite respectful.
employers.featuredReview.cons: The nature of the job itself - if considering this role is quite slow. You have some busy days and VERY slow moving days. Hopefully you're the mind of person who values down time because it could be frustrating, surprisingly.
employers.ceo.name: Sharen Turney
employers.ceo.title: CEO

employers.name: Nielsen
employers.featuredReview.headline: Scary smart, charismatic and motivated colleagues.
employers.featuredReview.pros: Nielsen really cares about providing value to its clients.  It is NOT about billing.  The culture is, "If the work adds differentiated value, new work follows." All levels of the organization get client interaction and the project teams encourage active participation from all team members - no matter what level they're at.  Teams are lean, so there is a lot of delegating, which provides ample opportunities to learn and stand apart from your peers.  Work life balance is tough - hours can be long, but they are flexible. Colleagues can work from home, take a day off, etc... as long as the work gets done on time and with the necessary content.  Sr. Leadership is brilliant and focused on growing the overall business.
employers.featuredReview.cons:
Salaries are low vs. comparable roles at a client organization or with other consulting firms.  Bonuses are stupid low.  Embarrassingly low.  Despite being a publicly traded company, there is no stock option plan or employee purchase plan for anyone other than the very, very select top management team.  As a result of this, there is a high turnover as more lucrative offers are very easy to come by. 

With numerous verticals (lines of business) it is difficult to gain cross-functional experience, as there is a strong push to keep people in one vertical, rather than move them and have to train them on new things.
employers.ceo.name: Mitch Barns
employers.ceo.title: Chief Executive Officer

employers.name: Rite Aid
employers.featuredReview.headline: Shift Supervisor

-Detailed training when you first start that continues monthly
